injury_prevention_tips: Use a yoga strap if you can't reach your foot.
Avoid if you have hip impingement pain.

instructions: Choose a flat bench and place a dumbbell on each side of it.

Place the right leg on top of the end of the bench, bend your torso forward from the waist until your upper body is parallel to the floor, and place your right hand on the other end of the bench for support.

Use the left hand to pick up the dumbbell on the floor and hold the weight while keeping your lower back straight. The palm of the hand should be facing your torso. This will be your starting position.

Pull the resistance straight up to the side of your chest, keeping your upper arm close to your side and keeping the torso stationary. Breathe out as you perform this step. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. Also, make sure that the force is performed with the back muscles and not the arms. Finally, the upper torso should remain stationary and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work except for holding the dumbbell; therefore do not try to pull the dumbbell up using the forearms.
Lower the resistance straight down to the starting position. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Repeat the movement for the specified amount of repetitions.
Switch sides and repeat again with the other arm.
exercises.name: One-Arm Dumbbell Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place one knee and hand on a flat bench.
Hold a dumbbell in the opposite hand with arm extended.
Pull the dumbbell up toward your hip, keeping elbow close.
Lower the weight slowly.
form_cues: Keep your back flat (parallel to floor).
Pull with your elbow, not your wrist.
Squeeze your shoulder blade at the top.
common_mistakes: Rotating the torso to swing the weight up.
Jerking the weight instead of pulling smoothly.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your neck neutral (don't look up).
Ensure your supporting leg is stable.

instructions: Lie down on a flat bench with a dumbbell in one hand resting on top of your thigh. The palm of your hand with the dumbbell in it should be at a neutral grip.

By using your thighs to help you get the dumbbell up, clean the dumbbell so that you can hold it in front of you with your lifting arm being fully extended. Remember to maintain a neutral grip with this exercise. Your non lifting hand should be to the side holding the flat bench for better support. This will be your starting position.

Your arm with the weight should have a slight bend on your elbow in order to prevent stress at the biceps tendon. Begin by lowering your arm with the weight in it out in a wide arc until you feel a stretch on your chest. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Keep in mind that throughout the movement, your lifting arm should remain stationary; the movement should only occur at the shoulder joint.
Return your lifting arm back to the starting position as you squeeze your chest muscles and breathe out. Tip: Make sure to use the same arc of motion used to lower the weights.
Hold for a second at the contracted position and repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the exercise.
exercises.name: One-Arm Flat Bench Dumbbell Flye
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a bench holding a dumbbell in one hand.
Press the weight up with a slight elbow bend.
Lower the weight out to the side in a wide arc.
Bring the weight back up, squeezing the chest.
form_cues: Keep a slight bend in the elbow (don't lock out).
common_mistakes: Lowering the weight too low (shoulder impingement risk).
injury_prevention_tips: Use a lighter weight than you think you need.
Stop if you feel pain in the front of the shoulder.

instructions: Connect a standard handle to a tower. Move cable to highest pulley position.
Stand with side to cable. With one hand, reach up and grab handle with underhand grip.
Pull down cable until elbow touches your side and the handle is by your shoulder.
Position feet hip-width apart. Place free hand on hip to help gauge pivot point.
Keep arm in static position. Contract oblique to bring the weight down in a side crunch.
Once you reach maximum contraction, slowly release the weight to the starting position. The weight stack should never be unloaded in a resting position. The aim is constant tension during the set.
Repeat to failure.
Then, reposition and repeat the same series of movements on the opposite side.
exercises.name: One-Arm High-Pulley Cable Side Bends
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a cable pulley to the highest position.
Stand sideways to the machine and grab the handle.
Keep your arm locked at your side.
Bend laterally toward the opposite side, then return to center.
form_cues: Keep hips forward (don't push hips back).
Keep the cable arm pinned to your side.
common_mistakes: Pulling with the arm instead of the obliques.
Rocking your hips back and forth.
injury_prevention_tips: Use light weight to avoid spinal compression.
Keep the movement controlled to protect the lower back.

instructions: Lie down sideways on an incline bench press with a dumbbell in the hand. Make sure the shoulder is pressing against the incline bench and the arm is lying across your body with the palm around your navel.
Hold a dumbbell in your uppermost arm while keeping it extended in front of you parallel to the floor. This is your starting position.

While keeping the dumbbell parallel to the floor at all times, perform a lateral raise. Your arm should travel straight up until it is pointing at the ceiling. Tip: Exhale as you perform this movement. Hold the dumbbell in the position and feel the contraction in the shoulders for a second.
While inhaling lower the weight across your body back into the starting position.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: One-Arm Incline Lateral Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie sideways on an incline bench.
Hold a dumbbell in your top hand, arm extended down.
Raise the dumbbell up toward the ceiling.
Lower back down slowly.
form_cues: Keep your arm parallel to the floor.
common_mistakes: Using momentum to swing the weight up.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the bench is secure.
Avoid if you have existing shoulder impingement.

instructions: Place a kettlebell between your feet. As you bend down to grab the kettlebell, push your butt back and keep your eyes looking forward.
Clean the kettlebell to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebell towards your shoulder. The wrist should rotate as you do so.
Return the weight to the starting position.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Clean
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place the kettlebell between your feet.
Hinge at the hips and grab the handle.
Explosively extend hips and knees to pull the bell up.
Flip the bell so it rests on your forearm at shoulder height.
form_cues: Keep the bell close to your body.
Punch your hand through at the top.
Absorb the weight with your legs, not your lower back.
common_mistakes: Letting the bell swing out away from the body.
Catching the weight with a stiff arm.
injury_prevention_tips: Practice the movement without weight first.
Keep your wrist straight to avoid strain.

instructions: Hold a kettlebell by the handle.
Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulder. Rotate your wrist as you do so, so that the palm faces forward.
Dip your body by bending the knees, keeping your torso upright.

Immediately reverse direction, driving through the heels, in essence jumping to create momentum. As you do so, press the kettlebell overhead to lockout by extending the arms, using your body's momentum to move the weight.
Receive the weight overhead by returning to a squat position underneath the weight.
Keeping the weight overhead, return to a standing position. Lower the weight to the floor to perform the next repetition.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Clean and Jerk
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder.
Dip your knees slightly.
Drive through your legs and press the bell overhead.
Lock out your arm and return the bell to the shoulder.
form_cues: Use leg drive to assist the press.
common_mistakes: Pressing with only the shoulder (no leg drive).
Leaning back too far during the press.
injury_prevention_tips: Master the clean and strict press separately first.
Ensure you have enough space overhead.

instructions: Lie on the floor holding a kettlebell with one hand, with your upper arm supported by the floor. The palm should be facing in.
Press the kettlebell straight up toward the ceiling, rotating your wrist.
Lower the kettlebell back to the starting position and repeat.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Floor Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on the floor with a kettlebell in one hand.
Pull the bell to your chest while keeping elbow tucked.
Press the bell straight up until arm is locked.
Lower back to chest.
form_cues: Keep your upper arm touching the floor.
common_mistakes: Letting the elbow flare out too wide.
Lifting your hips off the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Start light to protect the shoulder joint.
Keep the non-working hand on the floor for stability.

instructions: Hold a kettlebell by the handle. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulder. Rotate your wrist as you do so, so that the palm faces forward. This will be your starting position.
Dip your body by bending the knees, keeping your torso upright.

Immediately reverse direction, driving through the heels, in essence jumping to create momentum. As you do so, press the kettlebell overhead to lockout by extending the arms, using your body's momentum to move the weight. Receive the weight overhead by returning to a squat position underneath the weight. Keeping the weight overhead, return to a standing position.
Lower the weight to perform the next repetition.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Jerk
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder.
Dip down quickly by bending knees.
Drive up explosively and lock out the arm overhead.
Return to the start.
form_cues: Punch the floor with your legs.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a spotter or learn the bail-out technique.
Ensure the floor is not slippery.

instructions: Clean a kettlebell to your shoulder. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulder. Rotate your wrist as you do so, so that the palm faces inward. This will be your starting position.
Look at the kettlebell and press it up and out until it is locked out overhead.
Lower the kettlebell back to your shoulder under control and repeat. Make sure to contract your lat, butt, and stomach forcefully for added stability and strength.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Military Press To The Side
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder.
Press the bell straight up and slightly out to the side.
Lock out overhead.
Lower back to shoulder with control.
form_cues: Keep your lat engaged (pack the shoulder).
Keep your eyes on the bell.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the weight light until form is perfect.
Avoid if you feel clicking in the shoulder.

instructions: Clean a kettlebell to your shoulder. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulder. Rotate your wrist as you do so, so that the palm faces forward. This will be your starting position.
Hold the kettlebell with the elbow out to the side, and press it up and out until it is locked out overhead.
Lower the kettlebell back to your shoulder under control and repeat. Make sure to contract your lat, butt, and stomach forcefully for added stability and strength.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Para Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder.
Press the bell straight up overhead.
Lock out the arm.
Lower back to shoulder.
form_cues: Keep elbow tucked slightly in front of the body.
common_mistakes: Flaring the elbow out to the side.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the shoulder is warmed up.
Don't let the bell drift behind your head.

instructions: Hold a kettlebell by the handle. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulder. Rotate your wrist as you do so, so that the palm faces forward. This will be your starting position.
Dip your body by bending the knees, keeping your torso upright.

Immediately reverse direction, driving through the heels, in essence jumping to create momentum. As you do so, press the kettlebell overhead to lockout by extending the arms, using your body's momentum to move the weight. Lower the weight to perform the next repetition.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Push Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder.
Dip slightly by bending your knees.
Drive up explosively to help push the weight overhead.
Lock out and lower back down.
form_cues: Use leg drive to initiate the press.
Keep the elbow slightly in front of the bar.
common_mistakes: Not using the leg drive effectively.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your back straight; don't hyperextend.
Ensure you have good knee stability.

instructions: Place a kettlebell in front of your feet. Bend your knees slightly and then push your butt out as much as possible as you bend over to get in the starting position. Grab the kettlebell and pull it to your stomach, retracting your shoulder blade and flexing the elbow. Keep your back straight. Lower and repeat.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place the kettlebell slightly in front of you.
Hinge at the hips and grab the handle.
Pull the bell toward your hip.
Lower back down with control.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your neck neutral.
Ensure your grip is secure.

instructions: Place a kettlebell between your feet. Bend your knees and push your butt back to get in the proper starting position.
Look straight ahead and swing the kettlebell back between your legs.

Immediately reverse the direction and drive through with your hips and knees, accelerating the kettlebell upward. As the kettlebell rises to your shoulder rotate your hand and punch straight up, using momentum to receive the weight locked out overhead.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Snatch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start with the bell between your feet.
Hinge and pull the bell up explosively.
As it reaches chest height, punch your hand straight up.
Lock out overhead and absorb the weight.
form_cues: Keep the bell close to your body.
common_mistakes: Letting the bell flip over the top of the hand.
Catching the weight with a bent wrist.
injury_prevention_tips: Master the clean before attempting the snatch.
Use a chalk to prevent slipping.

instructions: Hold a kettlebell by the handle. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulder. Rotate your wrist as you do so, so that the palm faces forward. This will be your starting position.
Dip your body by bending the knees, keeping your torso upright.

Immediately reverse direction, driving through the heels, in essence jumping to create momentum. As you do so, press the kettlebell overhead to lockout by extending the arms, using your body's momentum to move the weight.
Receive the weight overhead by returning to a squat position underneath the weight, positioning one leg in front of you and one leg behind you.
Keeping the weight overhead, return to a standing position and bring your feet together. Lower the weight to perform the next repetition.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Split Jerk
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder.
Dip and drive up explosively.
Split your legs (one forward, one back) to catch the weight overhead.
Bring feet together and lower the weight.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure you have enough room for the split.
Practice the split footwork without weight first.

instructions: Hold a kettlebell in one hand by the handle.
Squat towards the floor, and then reverse the motion, extending the hips, knees, and finally the ankles, to raise the kettlebell overhead.

After fully extending the body, descend into a lunge position to receive the weights overhead, one leg forward and one leg back. Ensure you drive through with your hips and lock the ketttlebells overhead in one uninterrupted motion.
Return to a standing position, holding the weight overhead, and bring the feet together. Lower the weight to return to the starting position.
exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Split Snatch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start with the bell between your feet.
Explosively pull the bell up.
As you reach the top, split your legs to catch the bell overhead.
Stand up and bring feet together.
form_cues: Land stable in the lunge position.
common_mistakes: Catching the weight with a soft arm.
Landing with the feet too close together.
injury_prevention_tips: Master the standard snatch first.
Check your footing surface is not slippery.

exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Swings
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place the bell slightly in front of you.
Hinge at the hips and grab the handle.
Hike the bell back between your legs.
Snap your hips forward to swing the bell to chest height.
form_cues: This is a hip hinge, not a squat.
Squeeze your glutes at the top.
common_mistakes: Squatting the weight up instead of hinging.
Using your arms to lift the weight.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't swing too high (shoulder height is max).
Keep your spine neutral.

instructions: Position a bar into a landmine or in a corner to keep it from moving. Load an appropriate weight onto your end.
Stand next to the bar, and take a grip with one hand close to the collar. Using your hips and legs, rise to a standing position.
Assume a bent-knee stance with your hips back and your chest up. Your arm should be extended. This will be your starting position.
Pull the weight to your side by retracting the shoulder and flexing the elbow. Do not jerk the weight or cheat during the movement.
After a brief pause, return to the starting position.
exercises.name: One-Arm Long Bar Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a barbell in a landmine or corner.
Stand sideways to the bar and grab the end with one hand.
Hinge slightly at the hips and keep chest up.
Pull the bar toward your hip.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the bar is secure in the corner.
Keep your neck neutral.

instructions: Start in a standing position with a staggered, athletic stance. Hold a medicine ball in one hand, on the same side as your back leg. This will be your starting position.
Begin by winding the arm, raising the medicine ball above your head. As you do so, extend through the hips, knees, and ankles to load up for the slam.
At peak extension, flex the shoulders, spine, and hips to throw the ball hard into the ground directly in front of you.
Catch the ball on the bounce and continue for the desired number of repetitions.
exercises.name: One-Arm Medicine Ball Slam
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand in a staggered stance holding a medicine ball in one hand.
Raise the ball overhead, extending your body.
Slam the ball down forcefully between your feet.
Catch the bounce and repeat.
form_cues: Use your whole body to generate force.
Keep your arm straight during the slam.
common_mistakes: Bending too much at the waist.
Slamming the ball too far forward.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the floor can handle the impact.
Keep your back straight; don't round your spine.

instructions: Place one kettlebell between your feet.
Grab the handle with one hand and raise the kettlebell rapidly, let it flip so that the ball of the kettlebell lands in the palm of your hand.
Throw the kettlebell out in front of you and catch the handle with one hand.
Take the kettlebell to the floor and repeat. Make sure to work both arms.
exercises.name: One-Arm Open Palm Kettlebell Clean
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place the bell between your feet.
Pull the bell up explosively.
Let the bell flip so the ball rests in your open palm.
Catch it and lower back down.
common_mistakes: Catching the bell with a bent wrist.
Letting the bell fly too far out.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a light weight.
Use chalk for a better grip.

instructions: Clean and press a kettlebell with one arm. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulder. Rotate your wrist as you do so. Press the weight overhead by extending through the elbow.This will be your starting position.
Looking straight ahead and keeping a kettlebell locked out above you, flex the knees and hips and lower your torso between your legs, keeping your head and chest up.
Pause at the bottom position for a second before rising back to the top, driving through the heels of your feet.
exercises.name: One-Arm Overhead Kettlebell Squats
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean and press the kettlebell overhead with one arm.
Keep the bell locked out overhead.
Squat down until thighs are parallel to the floor.
Stand back up while keeping the bell stable.
common_mistakes: Leaning too far to one side.
injury_prevention_tips: Master the overhead press and goblet squat separately first.
Ensure you have full shoulder mobility.

instructions: Stand to the side of a barbell next to its center. Bend your knees and lower your body until you are able to reach the barbell.

Grasp the bar as if you were grabbing a briefcase (palms facing you since the bar is sideways). You may need a wrist wrap if you are using a significant amount of weight. This is your starting position.
Use your legs to help lift the barbell up while exhaling. Your arms should extend fully as bring the barbell up until you are in a standing position.
Slowly bring the barbell back down while inhaling. Tip: Make sure to bend your knees while lowering the weight to avoid any injury from occurring.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: One-Arm Side Deadlift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand next to a barbell on the floor.
Grab the bar with one hand (suitcase style).
Keep your back straight and chest up.
Stand up by driving through your legs.
form_cues: Squeeze the glutes at the top.
common_mistakes: Leaning the torso to the side.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight to master stability.
Keep your core braced tightly.

instructions: Pick a dumbbell and place it in one of your hands. Your non lifting hand should be used to grab something steady such as an incline bench press. Lean towards your lifting arm and away from the hand that is gripping the incline bench as this will allow you to keep your balance.
Stand with a straight torso and have the dumbbell by your side at arm length with the palm of the hand facing you. This will be your starting position.

While maintaining the torso stationary (no swinging), lift the dumbbell to your side with a slight bend on the elbow and your hand slightly tilted forward as if pouring water in a glass. Continue to go up until you arm is parallel to the floor. Exhale as you execute this movement and pause for a second at the top.
Lower the dumbbell back down slowly to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the exercise.
exercises.name: One-Arm Side Laterals
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a dumbbell in one hand.
Lean slightly to the side of the weight.
Raise the dumbbell out to the side until arm is parallel to the floor.
Lower back down slowly.
form_cues: Keep a slight bend in the elbow.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a light weight to protect the rotator cuff.
Don't go too high (stop at shoulder height).

instructions: Hook a leather ankle cuff to a low cable pulley and then attach the cuff to your ankle.
Face the weight stack from a distance of about two feet, grasping the steel frame for support.

While keeping your knees and hips bent slightly and your abs tight, contract your glutes to slowly kick the working leg back in a semicircular arc as high as it will comfortably go as you breathe out. Tip: At full extension, squeeze your glutes for a second in order to achieve a peak contraction.
Now slowly bring your working leg forward, resisting the pull of the cable until you reach the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch legs and repeat the movement for the other side.
exercises.name: One-Legged Cable Kickback
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach an ankle cuff to a low cable.
Face away from the machine and secure the cuff.
Keep your torso still and kick your leg straight back.
Return to the start with control.
form_cues: Squeeze your glute at the top.
Keep your standing leg slightly bent.
Keep your hips square to the front.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the weight light to avoid jerking.
Ensure the ankle cuff is secure.

instructions: From a standing position, place a bent arm against a wall or doorway.
Slowly lean toward your arm until you feel a stretch in your lats.
exercises.name: One Arm Against Wall
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand facing a wall.
Place one forearm flat against the wall.
Lean your body away from the wall.
Hold the stretch.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't force the stretch.
Avoid if you have shoulder pain.

instructions: For this exercise, start out by placing a towel around a chin up bar.
Grab the chin-up bar with your palm facing you. One hand will be grabbing the chin-up bar and the other will be grabbing the towel.
Bring your torso back around 30 degrees or so while creating a curvature on your lower back and sticking your chest out. This is your starting position.v

Pull your torso up until the bar touches your upper chest by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. The upper torso should remain stationary as it moves through space and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work other than hold the bar.
After a second on the contracted position, start to inhale and slowly lower your torso back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended and the lats are fully stretched.
Repeat this motion for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: One Arm Chin-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab a pull-up bar with one hand (palm facing you).
Use a towel or other hand for assistance if needed.
Pull your chest up to the bar.
Lower yourself down slowly.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a resistance band for assistance.
Master regular chin-ups first.

instructions: Lie down on a flat bench with a dumbbell in one hand on top of your thigh.

By using your thigh to help you get the dumbbell up, clean the dumbbell up so that you can hold it in front of you at shoulder width. Use the hand you are not lifting with to help position the dumbbell over you properly.
Once at shoulder width, rotate your wrist forward so that the palm of your hand is facing away from you. This will be your starting position.

Bring down the weights slowly to your side as you breathe in. Keep full control of the dumbbell at all times. Tip: Use the hand that you are not lifting with to help keep the dumbbell balance as you may struggle a bit at first. Only use your non-lifting hand if it is needed. Otherwise, keep it resting to the side.

As you breathe out, push the dumbbells up using your pectoral muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, squeeze your chest, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions of your training program.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: One Arm Dumbbell Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a bench holding a dumbbell in one hand.
Press the weight up until your arm is locked.
Lower the weight slowly to your chest.
Press back up.
common_mistakes: Lifting your hips off the bench.
injury_prevention_tips: Start light to learn the balance.
Use your non-working hand to help rack the weight.

instructions: Grab a dumbbell with the right arm and place the upper arm on top of the preacher bench or the incline bench. The dumbbell should be held at shoulder length. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, slowly lower the dumbbell until your upper arm is extended and the biceps is fully stretched.

As you exhale, use the biceps to curl the weight up until your biceps is fully contracted and the dumbbell is at shoulder height. Again, remember that to ensure full contraction you need to bring that small finger higher than the thumb.
Squeeze the biceps hard for a second at the contracted position and repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: One Arm Dumbbell Preacher Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a preacher bench and hold a dumbbell in one hand.
Place your upper arm on the pad.
Curl the weight up until your bicep is fully contracted.
Lower the weight slowly.
form_cues: Keep your upper arm glued to the pad.
common_mistakes: Lifting your upper arm off the pad.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't hyperextend the elbow at the bottom.
Use a lighter weight to avoid tendon strain.

instructions: Lie down on a flat surface with your back pressing against the floor or an exercise mat. Make sure your knees are bent.

Have a partner hand you the bar on one hand. When starting, your arm should be just about fully extended, similar to the starting position of a barbell bench press. However, this time your grip will be neutral (palms facing your torso).
Make sure the hand you are not using to lift the weight is placed by your side.
Begin the exercise by lowering the barbell until your elbow touches the ground. Make sure to breathe in as this is the eccentric (lowering part of the exercise).
Then start lifting the barbell back up to the original starting position. Remember to breathe out during the concentric (lifting part of the exercise).
Repeat until you have performed your recommended repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: One Arm Floor Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on the floor holding a barbell or dumbbell in one hand.
Lower the weight until your upper arm touches the floor.
Press the weight back up to lockout.
Repeat.
form_cues: Keep your upper arm resting on the floor.
common_mistakes: Bouncing the weight off the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a spotter or safety arms if using a heavy barbell.
Keep your non-working hand on the floor for stability.

instructions: Select an appropriate weight and adjust the knee pad to help keep you down. Grasp the handle with a pronated grip. This will be your starting position.
Pull the handle down, squeezing your elbow to your side as you flex the elbow.
Pause at the bottom of the motion, and then slowly return the handle to the starting position.
For multiple repetitions, avoid completely returning the weight to keep tension on the muscles being worked.
exercises.name: One Arm Lat Pulldown
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a lat pulldown machine and adjust the knee pad.
Grab the handle with one hand.
Pull the handle down to your chest.
Return the handle up slowly.
form_cues: Drive your elbow down and back.
common_mistakes: Pulling with your bicep instead of your back.
Using momentum by leaning back too far.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't let the weight stack slam up.
Keep your shoulder down before pulling.

instructions: Lie flat on a bench while holding a dumbbell at arms length. Your arm should be perpendicular to your body. The palm of your hand should be facing towards your feet as a pronated grip is required to perform this exercise.
Place your non lifting hand on your bicep for support.
Slowly begin to lower the dumbbell down as you breathe in.
Then, begin lifting the dumbbell upward as you contract the triceps. Remember to breathe out during the concentric (lifting part of the exercise).
Repeat until you have performed your set repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: One Arm Pronated Dumbbell Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a bench holding a dumbbell with a palm-down grip.
Extend your arm straight up.
Lower the weight behind your head by bending your elbow.
Extend back up.
form_cues: Squeeze the tricep at the top.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't hyperextend the elbow.
Use a lighter weight to protect the joint.

instructions: Lie flat on a bench while holding a dumbbell at arms length. Your arm should be perpendicular to your body. The palm of your hand should be facing towards your face as a supinated grip is required to perform this exercise.
Place your non lifting hand on your bicep for support.
Slowly begin to lower the dumbbell down as you breathe in.
Then, begin lifting the dumbbell upward as you contract the triceps. Remember to breathe out during the concentric (lifting part of the exercise).
Repeat until you have performed your set repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.
Switch arms again and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: One Arm Supinated Dumbbell Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a bench holding a dumbbell with a palm-up grip.
Extend your arm straight up.
Lower the weight behind your head.
Extend back up.
injury_prevention_tips: Control the weight carefully.
Stop if you feel elbow pain.

instructions: Lie facedown on the floor.
Put your left hand under your left hipbone to pad your hip and pubic bone.
Bend your right knee so you can hold the foot in your right hand.

Lift the foot in the air and simultaneously lift your shoulders off the floor. This also stretches the right hip flexor and the chest and shoulders. Switch sides. If it doesn't bother your back, you can try it with both arms and legs at the same time.
exercises.name: One Half Locust
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on the floor.
Bend one knee and grab your foot with your hand.
Lift your chest and your foot simultaneously.
Lower back down and switch sides.
form_cues: Keep your hips pressed into the floor.
common_mistakes: Letting the knee drop to the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Be gentle with your lower back.
Skip this if you have lower back pain.

instructions: Grab onto a chinup bar with one hand, using a pronated grip. Keep your feet on the floor or a step. Allow the majority of your weight to hang from that hand, while keeping your feet on the ground. Hold for 10-20 seconds and switch sides.
exercises.name: One Handed Hang
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab a pull-up bar with one hand.
Keep your feet on the floor or a step.
Let your body hang, putting weight on the arm.
Hold for time, then switch sides.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't jump off the bar; step down gently.
Use a towel if the bar is thin and hurts your hand.

instructions: Start off by lying on the floor.
Extend one leg straight and pull the other knee to your chest. Hold under the knee joint to protect the kneecap.
Gently tug that knee toward your nose.
Switch sides. This stretches the buttocks and lower back of the bent leg and the hip flexor of the straight leg.
exercises.name: One Knee To Chest
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back.
Pull one knee toward your chest.
Hold the back of your thigh (not the knee).
Hold the stretch, then switch sides.
form_cues: Keep your lower back on the floor.
common_mistakes: Pulling on the shin (bad for knee).
Lifting your hips off the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the stretch gentle.
Avoid if you have acute lower back pain.

instructions: Start by standing about 2 to 3 feet in front of a flat bench with your back facing the bench. Have a barbell in front of you on the floor. Tip: Your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other.
Bend the knees and use a pronated grip with your hands being wider than shoulder width apart from each other to lift the barbell up until you can rest it on your chest.

Then lift the barbell over your head and rest it on the base of your neck. Move one foot back so that your toe is resting on the flat bench. Your other foot should be stationary in front of you. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. Tip: Make sure your back is straight and chest is out while performing this exercise.
As you inhale, slowly lower your leg until your thigh is parallel to the floor. At this point, your knee should be over your toes. Your chest should be directly above the middle of your thigh.
Leading with the chest and hips and contracting the quadriceps, elevate your leg back to the starting position as you exhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch legs and repeat the movement.
exercises.name: One Leg Barbell Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a barbell across your upper back.
Place one foot on a bench behind you.
Squat down with your front leg until parallel.
Drive back up through the front heel.
form_cues: Keep your front knee tracking over your toes.
Keep your back foot lightly on the bench.
common_mistakes: Letting the front knee cave inward.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with bodyweight only.
Ensure your knee is stable before adding weight.

instructions: Place one kettlebell between your feet. Clean the kettlebell by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebell towards your shoulders.
Release the kettlebell as it comes up, and let it flip so that the ball of the kettlebell lands in the palms of your hands.
Release the kettlebell out in front of you and catch the handle with both hands. Lower the kettlebell to the starting position and repeat.
exercises.name: Open Palm Kettlebell Clean
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place the bell between your feet.
Pull the bell up explosively.
Flip the bell so the ball lands in your open palm.
Catch it and lower down.
injury_prevention_tips: Start light.
Use chalk.

instructions: Secure your feet and lay back on the floor. Your knees should be bent. Hold a weight with both hands to your chest. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by flexing the hips and spine to raise your torso up from the ground.
As you move up, press the weight up so that it is above your head at the top of the movement.
Return the weight to your chest as you reverse the sit-up motion, ensuring not to go all the way down to the floor.
exercises.name: Otis-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back holding a weight to your chest.
Perform a sit-up.
As you reach the top, press the weight overhead.
Lower the weight to your chest and reverse the sit-up.
form_cues: Keep the weight close to your body on the way up.
Press straight up at the top.
injury_prevention_tips: Start without weight to master the movement.
Don't flatten your lower back completely at the bottom.

instructions: To begin, set a weight that is comfortable on each side of the pulley machine. Note: Make sure that the amount of weight selected is the same on each side.
Now adjust the height of the pulleys on each side and make sure that they are positioned at a height higher than that of your shoulders.

Stand in the middle of both sides and use an underhand grip (palms facing towards the ceiling) to grab each handle. Your arms should be fully extended and parallel to the floor with your feet positioned shoulder width apart from each other. Your body should be evenly aligned the handles. This is the starting position.
While exhaling, slowly squeeze the biceps on each side until your forearms and biceps touch.
While inhaling, move your forearms back to the starting position. Note: Your entire body is stationary during this exercise except for the forearms.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions prescribed in your program.
exercises.name: Overhead Cable Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set cable pulleys higher than your head.
Stand in the middle and grab handles with palms up.
Curl your hands down toward your shoulders.
Return to the start slowly.
form_cues: Keep your upper arms parallel to the floor.
Squeeze the biceps at the bottom.
common_mistakes: Moving the elbows forward or back.
Using body English to move the weight.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your wrists straight.
Don't lock out your elbows at the top.

instructions: Sit upright on the floor with your partner behind you. Raise one arm straight up, and flex the elbow, attempting to touch your hand to your back. Your parner should hold your tricep and wrist. This will be your starting position.
Attempt to pull your upper arm to your side as your partner prevents you from doing actually doing so.
After 10-20 seconds, relax the arm and allow your partner to further stretch the lat by applying gentle pressure to the tricep. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then switch sides.
exercises.name: Overhead Lat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit upright with a partner behind you.
Raise one arm straight up, then bend your elbow to touch your back.
Keep your arm in that position while your partner holds your wrist and tricep.
Try to pull your upper arm down, but your partner resists for 10-20 seconds. Then relax and let them gently push your arm further for another 10-20 seconds.
form_cues: Keep your torso upright and don't lean back.
Only your upper arm should move during the resistance phase.
Communicate with your partner to ensure pressure is firm but not painful.
common_mistakes: Allowing the partner to push too hard, causing pain.
Moving the torso instead of isolating the lat.
Not relaxing after the isometric hold to maximize the stretch.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a slow, controlled motion during the passive stretch.
Avoid forcing the joint past its comfortable range of motion.

instructions: Standing straight up, lace your fingers together and open your palms to the ceiling. Keep your shoulders down as you extend your arms up.
To create a full torso stretch, pull your tailbone down and stabilize your torso as you do this. Stretch the muscles on both the front and the back of the torso.
exercises.name: Overhead Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall with feet shoulder-width apart.
Interlace your fingers and turn your palms up toward the ceiling.
Keep your shoulders relaxed and away from your ears.
Reach upward while gently pulling your tailbone down to lengthen your spine.
form_cues: Engage your glutes to protect your lower back.
Keep your arms straight but not locked out.
common_mistakes: Shrugging shoulders up to the ears.
injury_prevention_tips: If you have shoulder impingement, limit the range of motion slightly.
Move slowly; avoid bouncing.

instructions: Sit upright on the floor with your partner behind you. Raise one arm straight up, and flex the elbow, attempting to touch your hand to your back. Your parner should hold your elbow and wrist. This will be your starting position.
Attempt to extend the arm straight into the air as your partner prevents you from doing actually doing so.
After 10-20 seconds, relax the arm and allow your partner to further stretch the tricep by applying gentle pressure to the wrist. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then switch sides.
exercises.name: Overhead Triceps
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit upright with a partner behind you.
Raise one arm straight up, then bend your elbow to touch your back.
Keep your arm in that position while your partner holds your wrist and elbow.
Try to extend your arm up, but your partner resists for 10-20 seconds. Then relax and let them gently pull your wrist down for another 10-20 seconds.
form_cues: Keep your elbow pointing toward the ceiling.
common_mistakes: Shrugging the shoulder during the stretch.
injury_prevention_tips: Stop immediately if you feel sharp pain in the elbow joint.
Ensure the partner supports the arm, don't let it hang loose.

instructions: Connect a standard handle to a tower, and possibleposition the cable to shoulder height. If not, a low pulley will suffice.
With your side to the cable, grab the handle with both hands and step away from the tower. You should be approximately arm length away from the pulley, with the tension of the weight on the cable.
With your feet positioned hip-width apart and knees slightly bent, hold the cable to the middle of your chest. This will be your starting position.
Press the cable away from your chest, fully extending both arms. You core should be tight and engaged.
Hold the repetition for several seconds before returning to the starting position.
At the conclusion of the set, repeat facing the other direction.
exercises.name: Pallof Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a cable machine to shoulder height.
Stand sideways to the machine and grab the handle with both hands.
Step away until there is tension, feet hip-width apart, knees slightly bent.
Press the handle straight out in front of your chest, hold for 2-3 seconds, and return slowly.
form_cues: Brace your core like you're about to be punched.
Keep hips square to the front; don't let them rotate.
common_mistakes: Letting the cable pull your torso sideways.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight to master the anti-rotation aspect.
Wear flat-soled shoes for stability.

instructions: Connect a standard handle to a tower, and position the cable to shoulder height.

With your side to the cable, grab the handle with one hand and step away from the tower. You should be approximately arm length away from the pulley, with the tension of the weight on the cable. Align outstretched arm with cable.
With your feet positioned hip-width apart, pull the cable into your chest and grab the handle with your other hand. Both hands should be on the handle at this time.
Facing forward, press the cable away from your chest. You core should be tight and engaged.
Keeping your hips straight, twist your torso away from the pulley until you get a full quarter rotation.
Maintain your rigid stance and straight arms. Return to the neutral position in a slow and controlled manner. Your arms should be extended in front of you.
With the side tension still engaging your core, bring your hands to your chest and immediately press outward to a fully extended position. This constitutes one rep.
Repeat to failure.
Then, reposition and repeat the same series of movements on the opposite side.
exercises.name: Pallof Press With Rotation
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a cable machine to shoulder height.
Stand sideways to the machine and grab the handle with one hand.
Step away, then bring your other hand to the handle.
Press out, then rotate your torso away from the machine until your arms are perpendicular to the cable. Return to center.
form_cues: Control the rotation; don't let momentum swing you.
common_mistakes: Letting the hips rotate faster than the shoulders (disconnection).
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your spine neutral; avoid twisting into excessive extension.
Use a lighter weight than standard Pallof Press.

instructions: Start out by placing two dumbbells on one side of a flat bench.
Kneel down on both of your knees so that your body is facing the flat bench.

Use your arms to grab both of the dumbbells with a pronated grip (palms facing down) and bring them up so that your forearms are resting against the flat bench. Your wrists should be hanging over the edge.
Start out by curling your wrist upwards and exhaling.
Slowly lower your wrists back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Your forearms should be stationary as your wrist is the only movement needed to perform this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Palms-Down Dumbbell Wrist Curl Over A Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Kneel next to a bench with two dumbbells on it.
Rest your forearms on the bench with your wrists hanging off the edge, palms facing down.
Curl your wrists up toward your body.
Lower the weights slowly to stretch the forearms.
form_cues: Only move the wrists; forearms stay planted.
Keep elbows tucked into your sides.
Squeeze at the top of the movement.
common_mistakes: Using too much weight, causing sloppy form.
injury_prevention_tips: Start light to avoid tendon strain.
Ensure your wrists don't hyperextend at the bottom.

instructions: Start out by placing a barbell on one side of a flat bench.
Kneel down on both of your knees so that your body is facing the flat bench.
Use your arms to grab the barbell with a pronated grip (palms down) and bring them up so that your forearms are resting against the flat bench. Your wrists should be hanging over the edge.
Start out by curling your wrist upwards and exhaling.
Slowly lower your wrists back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Your forearms should be stationary as your wrist is the only movement needed to perform this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Palms-Down Wrist Curl Over A Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Kneel next to a bench with a barbell.
Rest your forearms on the bench with wrists hanging off, palms facing down.
Curl the bar up by flexing your wrists.
Lower the bar slowly to stretch the forearms.
form_cues: Keep forearms flush against the bench.
common_mistakes: Using momentum to swing the weight up.
Gripping too tightly, causing forearm cramps.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a lighter bar or dumbbells if you feel wrist pain.
Don't let the bar roll out of your fingers.

instructions: Start out by placing a barbell on one side of a flat bench.
Kneel down on both of your knees so that your body is facing the flat bench.
Use your arms to grab the barbell with a supinated grip (palms up) and bring them up so that your forearms are resting against the flat bench. Your wrists should be hanging over the edge.
Start out by curling your wrist upwards and exhaling.
Slowly lower your wrists back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Your forearms should be stationary as your wrist is the only movement needed to perform this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Palms-Up Barbell Wrist Curl Over A Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Kneel next to a bench with a barbell.
Rest your forearms on the bench with wrists hanging off, palms facing up.
Curl the bar up by flexing your wrists toward your forearms.
Lower the bar slowly to stretch the forearms.
form_cues: Keep wrists neutral at the bottom (don't hyperextend).
common_mistakes: Using weight that is too heavy.
injury_prevention_tips: Stop if you feel pain in the wrist joint.
Ensure the bench supports the forearm fully.

instructions: Start out by placing two dumbbells on one side of a flat bench.
Kneel down on both of your knees so that your body is facing the flat bench.
Use your arms to grab both of the dumbbells with a supinated grip (palms up) and bring them up so that your forearms are resting against the flat bench. Your wrists should be hanging over the edge.
Start out by curling your wrist upwards and exhaling.
Slowly lower your wrists back down to the starting position while inhaling. Make sure to inhale during this part of the exercise.
Your forearms should be stationary as your wrist is the only movement needed to perform this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Palms-Up Dumbbell Wrist Curl Over A Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Kneel next to a bench with two dumbbells.
Rest your forearms on the bench with wrists hanging off, palms facing up.
Curl the dumbbells up by flexing your wrists.
Lower them slowly to stretch the forearms.
form_cues: Squeeze the forearms at the top.
common_mistakes: Rotating the wrists during the movement.
Letting dumbbells roll out of hands.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a controlled tempo to protect tendons.
Ensure wrists don't hyperextend at the bottom.

instructions: Lie down with your feet on the floor, heels directly under your knees.
Lift only your tailbone to the ceiling to stretch your lower back. (Don't lift the entire spine yet.) Pull in your stomach.
To go into a bridge, lift the entire spine except the neck.
exercises.name: Pelvic Tilt Into Bridge
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor.
Lift your tailbone slightly off the floor (posterior pelvic tilt).
Engage your abs and glutes.
Lift your entire spine off the floor until you form a bridge, then lower slowly.
form_cues: Drive through your heels to lift.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the movement slow and controlled to protect the lumbar spine.
Avoid if you have acute lower back pain.

instructions: Lay on your side, supporting your weight on your forearm and on a foam roller placed on the outside of your lower leg. Your upper leg can either be on top of your lower leg, or you can cross it in front of you. This will be your starting position.
Raise your hips off of the ground and begin to roll from below the knee to above the ankle on the side of your leg, pausing at points of tension for 10-30 seconds. Repeat on the other leg.
exercises.name: Peroneals-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your side with a foam roller under the outside of your lower leg.
Support your weight with your forearm and top leg.
Roll from just below the knee to above the ankle.
Pause on tender spots for 20-30 seconds.
form_cues: Keep your core engaged to avoid tipping over.
Point your toes slightly down to target the peroneals.
common_mistakes: Putting too much weight on the roller (causing pain).
Rolling directly over the ankle bone.
injury_prevention_tips: Avoid the bony parts of the ankle.
Do not force the muscle if it feels bruised.

instructions: In a seated position, loop a belt, rope, or band around one foot. This will be your starting position.

With the leg extended and the heel off of the ground, pull on the belt so that the foot is inverted, with the inside of the foot being pulled towards you. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then switch sides.
exercises.name: Peroneals Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with one leg extended.
Loop a band or towel around the foot.
Pull the foot inward (inversion) so the sole faces your other leg.
Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds.
form_cues: Keep your knee straight but not locked.
injury_prevention_tips: Warm up the ankles before stretching.
Stop if you feel sharp pain.

instructions: Lay on a ball so that your upper back is on the ball with your hips unsupported. Both feet should be flat on the floor, hip width apart or wider. This will be your starting position.
Begin by extending the hips using your glutes and hamstrings, raising your hips upward as you bridge.
Pause at the top of the motion and return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Physioball Hip Bridge
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the ball, then roll down until your upper back is resting on it.
Place feet flat on the floor, hip-width apart.
Drive through your heels to lift your hips toward the ceiling.
Lower hips back down slowly.
form_cues: Keep your chin tucked (don't look at the ceiling).
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the ball is properly inflated so it doesn't slip.
Keep feet wide enough for stability.

instructions: Pin presses remove the eccentric phase of the bench press, developing starting strength. They also allow you to train a desired range of motion.

The bench should be set up in a power rack. Set the pins to the desired point in your range of motion, whether it just be lockout or an inch off of your chest. The bar should be moved to the pins and prepared for lifting.

Begin by lying on the bench, with the bar directly above the contact point during your regular bench. Tuck your feet underneath you and arch your back. Using the bar to help support your weight, lift your shoulder off the bench and retract them, squeezing the shoulder blades together. Use your feet to drive your traps into the bench. Maintain this tight body position throughout the movement.
You can take a standard bench grip, or shoulder width to focus on the triceps. The bar, wrist, and elbow should stay in line at all times. Focus on squeezing the bar and trying to pull it apart.
Drive the bar up with as much force as possible. The elbows should be tucked in until lockout.
Return the bar to the pins, pausing before beginning the next repetition.
exercises.name: Pin Presses
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set pins in a power rack just below your chest or at sticking point.
Lie on the bench and set up tight (shoulders retracted).
Unrack the bar from the pins.
Lower the bar to the pins, pause, then explode up.
form_cues: Keep your shoulder blades squeezed together.
Drive your feet into the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure pins are set securely.
Don't use this variation if you have shoulder impingement.

instructions: Sit with your buttocks on top of a foam roll. Bend your knees, and then cross one leg so that the ankle is over the knee. This will be your starting position.

Shift your weight to the side of the crossed leg, rolling over the buttocks until you feel tension in your upper glute. You may assist the stretch by using one hand to pull the bent knee towards your chest. Hold this position for 10-30 seconds, and then switch sides.
exercises.name: Piriformis-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a foam roller with one ankle crossed over the opposite knee.
Shift your weight onto the glute of the crossed leg.
Roll over the glute area until you find a tender spot.
Hold the spot for 20-30 seconds.
form_cues: Breathe deeply to relax the muscle.
injury_prevention_tips: Avoid the lower back; focus on the glute.
Do not force the stretch if it causes sciatic nerve pain.

instructions: Get into a prone position on the floor, supporting your weight on your toes and your forearms. Your arms are bent and directly below the shoulder.
Keep your body straight at all times, and hold this position as long as possible. To increase difficulty, an arm or leg can be raised.
exercises.name: Plank
beginner_friendly_instructions: Get into a pushup position but rest on your forearms.
Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels.
Engage your core and glutes.
Hold the position without letting your hips sag.
form_cues: Keep your elbows directly under your shoulders.
Look at the floor slightly ahead of your hands.
injury_prevention_tips: If your lower back hurts, drop to your knees.
Ensure wrists are neutral if doing high plank.

instructions: Grab two wide-rimmed plates and put them together with the smooth sides facing outward
Use your fingers to grip the outside part of the plate and your thumb for the other side thus holding both plates together. This is the starting position.
Squeeze the plate with your fingers and thumb. Hold this position for as long as you can.
Repeat for the recommended amount of sets prescribed in your program.
Switch arms and repeat the movements.
exercises.name: Plate Pinch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Take two smooth-sided weight plates.
Press them together with the smooth sides facing out.
Pinch the plates between your fingers and thumb.
Lift them off the ground and hold for time.
form_cues: Keep your arm by your side.
common_mistakes: Using plates with ridges (harder to pinch).
Dropping the plates on your feet.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with lighter plates (e.g., 5-10 lbs).
Don't let the plates slip; if they do, let them fall safely.

instructions: Lie down on the floor or an exercise mat with your legs fully extended and your upper body upright. Grab the plate by its sides with both hands out in front of your abdominals with your arms slightly bent.

Slowly cross your legs near your ankles and lift them up off the ground. Your knees should also be bent slightly. Note: Move your upper body back slightly to help keep you balanced turning this exercise. This is the starting position.
Move the plate to the left side and touch the floor with it. Breathe out as you perform that movement.

Come back to the starting position as you breathe in and then repeat the movement but this time to the right side of the body. Tip: Use a slow controlled movement at all times. Jerking motions can injure the back.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Plate Twist
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with knees bent and feet hovering slightly off the ground.
Hold a weight plate with both hands in front of your chest.
Twist your torso to one side, touching the plate to the floor.
Twist to the other side and repeat.
form_cues: Move through the torso, not just the arms.
common_mistakes: Using momentum to swing the plate.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the weight light to moderate.
Move slowly to protect the spine.

instructions: For this movement a wooden floor or similar is needed. Lay on your back with your legs extended. Place a gym towel or a light weight underneath your heel. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by flexing the knee, keeping your other leg straight.
Continue bringing the heel closer to you, sliding it on the floor.
At full knee flexion, reverse the movement to return to the starting position.
exercises.name: Platform Hamstring Slides
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with legs straight.
Place a towel or slider under one heel.
Slide the heel toward your butt by bending the knee.
Slide back out to straighten the leg.
form_cues: Keep your hips on the floor.
Control the movement; don't let the leg snap back.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the surface is smooth to avoid catching.
Stop if you feel hamstring cramping.

instructions: Hold a dumbbell at the base with both hands and stand straight up. Move your legs so that they are wider than shoulder width apart from each other with your knees slightly bent.
Your toes should be facing out. Note: Your arms should be stationary while performing the exercise. This is the starting position.
Slowly bend the knees and lower your legs until your thighs are parallel to the floor. Make sure to inhale as this is the eccentric part of the exercise.
Press mainly with the heel of the foot to bring the body back to the starting position while exhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Plie Dumbbell Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold one dumbbell vertically against your chest.
Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width, toes pointed out.
Squat down by bending knees and pushing hips back.
Drive back up through your heels.
form_cues: Keep your chest up and proud.
Knees track in line with toes.
common_mistakes: Rising onto toes at the top.
injury_prevention_tips: Start without weight to master the stance.
Ensure your feet are turned out comfortably.

instructions: Place a kettlebell on the floor. Place yourself in a pushup position, on your toes with one hand on the ground and one hand holding the kettlebell, with your elbows extended. This will be your starting position.
Begin by lowering yourself as low as you can, keeping your back straight.

Quickly and forcefully reverse direction, pushing yourself up to the other side of the kettlebell, switching hands as you do so. Continue the movement by descending and repeating the movement back and forth.
exercises.name: Plyo Kettlebell Pushups
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a kettlebell on the floor.
Get into a pushup position with one hand on the bell and one on the floor.
Perform a pushup, then explosively push up to switch hands to the other side of the bell.
Repeat the switch with each rep.
form_cues: Keep your body in a straight line.
common_mistakes: Landing with a stiff arm (wrist injury risk).
Not getting enough height to clear the bell.
injury_prevention_tips: Master standard pushups first.
Ensure the kettlebell is stable and won't tip.

instructions: In a seated position, loop a belt, rope, or band around one foot. This will be your starting position.

With the leg extended and the heel off of the ground, pull on the belt so that the foot is everted, with the outside of the foot being pulled towards you. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then switch sides.
exercises.name: Posterior Tibialis Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with one leg extended.
Loop a band or towel around the foot.
Pull the foot outward (eversion) so the outside of the foot moves toward you.
Hold for 20-30 seconds.
injury_prevention_tips: Warm up the ankle first.
Stop if you feel pain on the inside of the ankle.

instructions: Stand with your feet slightly wider than shoulder width apart and toes pointing out slightly.
Squat down and grasp bar with a closed, pronated grip. Your hands should be slightly wider than shoulder width apart outside knees with elbows fully extended.
Place the bar about 1 inch in front of your shins and over the balls of your feet.
Your back should be flat or slightly arched, your chest held up and out and your shoulder blades should be retracted.
Keep your head in a neutral position (in line with vertebral column and not tilted or rotated) with your eyes focused straight ahead. Inhale during this phase.

Lift the bar from the floor by forcefully extending the hips and the knees as you exhale. Tip: The upper torso should maintain the same angle. Do not bend at the waist yet and do not let the hips rise before the shoulders (this would have the effect of pushing the glutes in the air and stretching the hamstrings.
Keep elbows fully extended with the head in a neutral position and the shoulders over the bar.
As the bar raises keep it as close to the shins as possible.
As the bar passes the knees, thrust your hips forward and slightly bend the knees to avoid locking them. Tip: At this point your thighs should be against the bar.
Keep the back flat or slightly arched, elbows fully extended and your head neutral. Tip: You will hold your breath until the next phase.
Inhale and then forcefully and quickly extend your hips and knees and stand on your toes.

Keep the bar as close to your body as possible. Tip: Your back should be flat with the elbows pointed out to the sides and your head in a neutral position. Also, keep your shoulders over the bar and arms straight as long as possible.
When your lower body joints are fully extended, shrug the shoulders upward rapidly without letting the elbows flex yet. Exhale during this portion of the movement.
As the shoulders reach their highest elevation flex your elbows to begin pulling your body under the bar.

Continue to pull the arms as high and as long as possible. Tip: Due to the explosive nature of this phase, your torso will be erect or with an arched back, your head will be tilted back slightly and your feet may lose contact with the floor.
After the lower body has fully extended and the bar reaches near maximal height, pull your body under the bar and rotate the arms around and under the bar.
Simultaneously, flex the hips and knees into a quarter squat position.
Once the arms are under the bar, inhale and then lift your elbows to position the upper arms parallel to the floor. Rack the bar across the front of your collar bones and front shoulder muscles.
Catch the bar with an erect and tight torso, a neutral head position and flat feet. Exhale during this movement.
Stand up by extending the hips and knees to a fully erect position.
Lower the bar by gradually reducing the muscular tension of the arms to allow a controlled descent of the bar to the thighs. Inhale during this movement.
Simultaneously flex the hips and knees to cushion the impact of the bar on the thighs.
Squat down with the elbows fully extended until the bar touches the floor.
Start over at Phase 1 and repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Power Clean
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, bar over mid-foot.
Hinge at hips and grip the bar, keeping back flat.
Explosively extend hips and knees, then shrug and pull the bar up.
Drop under the bar and catch it on your shoulders with a slight squat.
form_cues: Keep the bar close to your body.
Triple extension (ankles, knees, hips) is key.
Keep your chest up during the pull.
common_mistakes: Letting the bar drift away from the body.
Rounding the back off the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Learn the movement with a PVC pipe or empty bar first.
Use weightlifting shoes or flat, hard-soled shoes.

instructions: Stand up with your torso upright and a dumbbell on each hand being held at arms length. The elbows should be close to the torso.
The palms of the hands should be facing your torso. Your feet should be about shoulder width apart. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your arms straight and the torso stationary, lift the weights out to your sides until they are about shoulder level height while exhaling.

Feel the contraction for a second and begin to lower the weights back down to the starting position while inhaling. Tip: Keep the palms facing down with the little finger slightly higher while lifting and lowering the weights as it will concentrate the stress on your shoulders mainly.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Power Partials
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding dumbbells at your sides.
Lift the weights out to the side only up to shoulder height.
Pause briefly at the top.
Lower them back down with control.
form_cues: Keep a slight bend in elbows.
Lead with your pinky finger slightly higher than the thumb.
injury_prevention_tips: Start light to avoid shoulder impingement.
Don't go higher than shoulder height.

instructions: To perform this movement you will need a preacher bench and an E-Z bar. Grab the E-Z curl bar at the close inner handle (either have someone hand you the bar which is preferable or grab the bar from the front bar rest provided by most preacher benches). The palm of your hands should be facing forward and they should be slightly tilted inwards due to the shape of the bar.
With the upper arms positioned against the preacher bench pad and the chest against it, hold the E-Z Curl Bar at shoulder length. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, slowly lower the bar until your upper arm is extended and the biceps is fully stretched.
As you exhale, use the biceps to curl the weight up until your biceps is fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder height. Squeeze the biceps hard and hold this position for a second.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Preacher Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a preacher bench with an EZ-bar.
Grip the bar and rest your upper arms on the pad.
Curl the bar up toward your shoulders.
Lower it slowly until arms are nearly straight.
form_cues: Keep your armpits glued to the bench.
Squeeze the biceps at the top.
Control the weight on the way down.
common_mistakes: Lifting your elbows off the pad.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't hyperextend the elbow at the bottom.
Use a weight that allows full control.

instructions: Place the upper part of both arms on top of the preacher bench as you hold a dumbbell in each hand with the palms facing each other (neutral grip).
As you breathe in, slowly lower the dumbbells until your upper arm is extended and the biceps is fully stretched.
As you exhale, use the biceps to curl the weight up until your biceps is fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder height.
Squeeze the biceps hard for a second at the contracted position and repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Preacher Hammer Dumbbell Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a preacher bench holding dumbbells.
Rest upper arms on the pad with palms facing each other.
Curl the dumbbells up simultaneously.
Lower them slowly.
common_mistakes: Rotating wrists (turning into a regular curl).
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure dumbbells are secure in your grip.
Stop if you feel wrist strain.

instructions: To begin, lie down on a bench with a barbell resting on your chest. Position your legs so they are secure on the extension of the abdominal bench. This is the starting position.

While inhaling, tighten your abdominals and glutes. Simultaneously curl your torso as you do when performing a sit-up and press the barbell to an overhead position while exhaling. Tip: Use your arms to push the barbell out as you perform this exercise while still focusing on the abdominal muscles.
Lower your upper body back down to the starting position while bringing the barbell back down to your torso. Remember to breathe in while lowering the body.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Press Sit-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a decline bench with feet secured.
Hold a light barbell or plate on your chest.
Sit up while pressing the weight overhead.
Lower the weight as you lie back down.
common_mistakes: Letting the weight pull you forward.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weight or no weight.
Avoid if you have lower back issues.

instructions: You will need a partner for this exercise. Lay face down with your legs straight. Your assistant will place their hand on your heel.

To begin, flex the knee to curl your leg up. Your partner should provide resistance, starting light and increasing the pressure as the movement is completed. Communicate with your partner to monitor appropriate resistance levels.
Pause at the top, returning the leg to the starting position as your partner provides resistance going the other direction.
exercises.name: Prone Manual Hamstring
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on a bench or floor.
Have a partner hold your ankles.
Curl your legs up against your partner's resistance.
Lower slowly against resistance.
form_cues: Keep hips pressed into the bench.
Communicate with partner for appropriate resistance.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light resistance.
Ensure your partner knows how to spot safely.

instructions: Begin standing a few feet in front of a low pulley with a rope or handle attached. Face away from the machine, straddling the cable, with your feet set wide apart.

Begin the movement by reaching through your legs as far as possible, bending at the hips. Keep your knees slightly bent. Keeping your arms straight, extend through the hip to stand straight up. Avoid pulling upward through the shoulders; all of the motion should originate through the hips.
exercises.name: Pull Through
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand facing away from a low cable machine with a rope attachment.
Reach between your legs and grab the rope.
Hinge at the hips and let the weight pull you forward.
Drive your hips forward to stand up straight.
form_cues: Keep a slight bend in your knees.
common_mistakes: Using arms to pull instead of hips.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the weight light to master the hinge.
Don't let the weight pull you into a rounded back.

instructions: Grab the pull-up bar with the palms facing forward using the prescribed grip. Note on grips: For a wide grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance wider than your shoulder width. For a medium grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance equal to your shoulder width and for a close grip at a distance smaller than your shoulder width.

As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar at the chosen grip width, bring your torso back around 30 degrees or so while creating a curvature on your lower back and sticking your chest out. This is your starting position.

Pull your torso up until the bar touches your upper chest by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. The upper torso should remain stationary as it moves through space and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work other than hold the bar.
After a second on the contracted position, start to inhale and slowly lower your torso back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended and the lats are fully stretched.
Repeat this motion for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Pullups
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab the bar with an overhand grip, hands wider than shoulders.
Hang with arms fully extended.
Pull your chest toward the bar by driving elbows down.
Lower yourself slowly to the start.
form_cues: Start the movement by depressing your shoulder blades.
common_mistakes: Not going through full range of motion.
injury_prevention_tips: If you can't do a pullup, use bands or an assisted machine.
Avoid jerking your neck.

instructions: With your hands wide apart, support your body on your toes and hands in a plank position. Your elbows should be extended and your body straight. Do not allow your hips to sag. This will be your starting position.
To begin, allow the elbows to flex, lowering your chest to the floor as you inhale.
Using your pectoral muscles, press your upper body back up to the starting position by extending the elbows. Exhale as you perform this step.
After pausing at the contracted position, repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Push-Up Wide
beginner_friendly_instructions: Get into a plank position with hands wider than shoulders.
Lower your chest to the floor.
Keep your elbows tucked slightly.
Push back up to the start.
form_cues: Keep your body in a straight line.
Squeeze your chest at the top.
injury_prevention_tips: If wrists hurt, use pushup handles.
Don't go too low if you have shoulder issues.

instructions: Lie on the floor face down and place your hands closer than shoulder width for a close hand position. Make sure that you are holding your torso up at arms' length.
Lower yourself until your chest almost touches the floor as you inhale.
Using your triceps and some of your pectoral muscles, press your upper body back up to the starting position and squeeze your chest. Breathe out as you perform this step.
After a second pause at the contracted position, repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Push-Ups - Close Triceps Position
beginner_friendly_instructions: Get into a plank position with hands close together (under chest).
Lower your chest to your hands.
Keep elbows tucked close to your sides.
Push back up explosively.
form_cues: Keep your elbows tracking back, not flaring.
Hands should form a diamond shape.
injury_prevention_tips: Modify on knees if needed.
Keep wrists neutral.

instructions: Lie on the floor face down and place your hands about 36 inches apart from each other holding your torso up at arms length.
Place your toes on top of a flat bench. This will allow your body to be elevated. Note: The higher the elevation of the flat bench, the higher the resistance of the exercise is.
Lower yourself until your chest almost touches the floor as you inhale.
Using your pectoral muscles, press your upper body back up to the starting position and squeeze your chest. Breathe out as you perform this step.
After a second pause at the contracted position, repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
exercises.name: Push-Ups With Feet Elevated
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place your feet on a bench or box.
Get into a plank position with hands on the floor.
Lower your chest to the floor.
Push back up.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the bench is stable.
